words.def: abhidhamma A category of scriptures that attempts to use Buddhist teachings to create a systematic, abstract description of all worldly phenomena
words.name: abhidhamma

words.def: Abhidhamma Pitaka The third basket of the Tripitaka canon, the reorganization of all doctrines in a systematic way
words.name: Abhidhamma Pitaka

words.def: acariya, lit. "teacher", One of the two teachers of a novice monk - the other one is called upādhyāya
words.name: acariya

words.def: adhitthana Determination, to pray, to wish
words.name: adhitthana

words.def: Agama The non-Mahayana divisions of the Sutra Pitaka
words.name: Agama

words.def: ahimsa The devotion to non-violence and respect for all forms of life. Practicers of ahimsa are often vegetarians or vegans
words.name: ahimsa

words.def: alayavijnana, see store consciousness
words.name: alayavijnana

words.def: Amitabha Lit. "The Buddha of Infinite Light". The main buddha of the Pure Land school, but is popular in other Mahayana sects as well. The image is of light as the form of wisdom, which has no form. Also interpreted as the Tathagata of Unhindered Light that Penetrates the Ten Quarters by Tan Luan, Shinran and others
words.name: Amitabha

words.def: anagarika A white-robed student in the Theravada tradition who, for a few months, awaits being considered for Samaneras ordination
words.name: anagarika

words.def: anapanasati Mindfulness of the breath meditation
words.name: anapanasati

words.def: anatta The principle denial of the soul in any phenomena. See also negative theology.
words.name: anatta

words.def: anicca Impermanence
words.name: anicca

words.def: anuttara Unsurpassing
words.name: anuttara

words.def: arhat, lit. "the Worthy One", A living person who has reached Enlightenment
words.name: arhat

words.def: anuttara samyak sambodhi, unsurpassable, complete, perfect enlightenment; unsurpassable, right, and full enlightenment
words.name: anuttara samyak sambodhi

words.def: atman literally "self", sometimes "soul" or "ego". In Buddhism, the predominant teaching is the negating doctrine of anatman, that there is no permanent, persisting atman, and that belief in atman is the prime consequence of ignorance, the foundation of samsara
words.name: atman

words.def: Avalokitesvara, lit. "One Who Hears the Suffering Cries of the World", The bodhisattva of compassion (see also Guan Yin)
words.name: Avalokitesvara

words.def: avidya "ignorance" or "delusion"
words.name: avidya

words.def: bardo, lit. "intermediate state" or "in-between state", According to Tibetan tradition, the state of existence intermediate between two lives
words.name: bardo

words.def: bhavacakra/bhavacakka A circular symbolic representation of samsara, also known as Wheel of becoming
words.name: bhavacakra/bhavacakka

words.def: bhante The polite particle used to refer to Buddhist monks in the Theravada tradition. Bhante literally means "Venerable Sir."
words.name: bhante

words.def: bhava Becoming, being, existing; the 10th link of Pratitya-samutpada
words.name: bhava

words.def: bhikkhu/bhikshu, lit. "beggar", A Buddhist monk
words.name: bhikkhu/bhikshu

words.def: bhikkhuni/bhikshuni A Buddhist nun
words.name: bhikkhuni/bhikshuni

words.def: bija, lit. "seed", A metaphor for the origin or cause of things, used in the teachings of the Yogacara school
words.name: bija

words.def: bodhi Awakening or Enlightenment
words.name: bodhi

words.def: Bodhi tree The Sacred Fig (Ficus religiosa) tree under which Gautama reached Enlightenment
words.name: Bodhi tree

words.def: bodhicitta The motivation of a bodhisattva
words.name: bodhicitta

words.def: bodhisattva One with the intention to become a Buddha in order to liberate all other sentient beings from suffering
words.name: bodhisattva

words.def: Boghda Holy, living Buddha, living Boddhisattva. The title of Jebtsundamba Khutuktu; also title used with the names of highest Buddhist masters, e.g. boghda Tsongkhapa, Panchen boghda
words.name: Boghda

words.def: Buddha A Buddha; also, the Buddha Siddhārtha Gautama.
words.name: Buddha

words.def: buddha nature The uncreated and deathless Buddhic element or principle concealed within all sentient beings to achieve Awakening; the innate (latent) Buddha essence (esp. in the Tathagatagarbha sutras, Tendai/Tiantai, Nichiren thought)
words.name: buddha nature

words.def: cetana Volition
words.name: cetana

words.def: Cetiya A reliquary holding holy objects of veneration
words.name: Cetiya

words.def: dakini A supernatural female with volatile temperament who serves as a muse for spiritual practice. Dakinis are often depicted naked to represent the truth
words.name: dakini

words.def: Dalai Lama, lit. "the lama with wisdom like an ocean", secular and spiritual leader of Tibet as nominated by the Mongols
words.name: Dalai Lama

words.def: dana Generosity or giving; in Buddhism, it also refers to the practice of cultivating generosity
words.name: dana

words.def: deva many different types of non-human beings who share the characteristics of being more powerful, longer-lived, and, in general, living more contentedly than the average human being
words.name: deva

words.def: dependent origination, see Pratityasamutpada
words.name: dependent origination

words.def: dhamma/dharma Often refers to the doctrines and teachings of the faith, but it may have broader uses. Also, it is an important technical term meaning something like "phenomenological constituent." This leads to the potential for confusion, puns, and double entendres, as the latter meaning often has negative connotations
words.name: dhamma/dharma

words.def: dhammavinaya The dharma and vinaya (roughly "doctrine and discipline") considered together. This term essentially means the whole teachings of Buddhism as taught to monks
words.name: dhammavinaya

words.def: dhammacakka/dharmacakra A symbolic representation of the dharma, also known as the Wheel of Dharma
words.name: dhammacakka/dharmacakra

words.def: Dhammapada a versified Buddhist scripture traditionally ascribed to the Buddha
words.name: Dhammapada

words.def: dhammapala/dharmapala A fearsome deity, known as protector of the Dharma
words.name: dhammapala/dharmapala

words.def: Dhyana, see jhana
words.name: Dhyana

words.def: doan In Zen, a term for person sounding the bell that marks the beginning and end of Zazen
words.name: doan

words.def: dokusan A private meeting between a Zen student and the master. It is an important element in Rinzai Zen training, as it provides an opportunity for the student to demonstrate understanding
words.name: dokusan

words.def: dudie official certificate for monks and nuns issued by government
words.name: dudie

words.def: dukkha Suffering, dissatisfaction, stress
words.name: dukkha

words.def: dzogchen The natural, intrinsic state of every sentient being
words.name: dzogchen

words.def:
Five Five-Hundred-Year Periods Five sub-divisions of the three periods following the Buddha's passing (三時繫念 Cn: sānshí; Jp: sanji; Vi: tam thời), significant for many Mahayana adherents:

Age of enlightenment (解脱堅固 Cn: jiětuō jiāngù; Jp: gedatsu kengo)
Age of meditation (禅定堅固 Cn: chándìng jiāngù; Jp: zenjō kengo)
These two ages comprise the Former Day of the Law (正法時期 Cn: zhèngfǎ; Jp: shōbō)
Age of reading, reciting, and listening (読誦多聞堅固 Cn: sòngduōwén jiāngù; Jp: dokuju tamon kengo)
Age of building temples and stupas (多造塔寺堅固 Cn: duōzào tǎsì jiāngù; Jp: tazō tōji kengo)
These two ages comprise the Middle Day of the Law (像法時期 Cn: xiàngfǎ; Jp: zōhō)
Age of conflict (闘諍堅固 Cn: zhēng jiāngù; Jp: tōjō kengo), an age characterized by unrest, strife, famine, and other natural and human-made disasters.
This age corresponds to the beginning of the Latter Day of the Law (末法時期 Cn: mòfǎ; Jp: mappō) when the (historical) Buddha's teachings would lose all power of salvation and perish (白法隠没 Cn: báifǎméi; Jp: byakuhō onmotsu) and a new Buddha would appear to save the people.


The three periods and the five five-hundred year periods are described in the Sutra of the Great Assembly (大集 Cn: dàjí; Jp: Daishutu-kyō, Daijuku-kyō, Daijikkyō, or Daishukkyō).
words.name: Five Five-Hundred-Year Periods

words.def:
Four Noble Truths

Truth of dukkha (suffering, anxiety, stress) (Sanskrit: duḥkhāryasatya; Bur: ဒုက္ခ dokkha; Thai: ทุกข์; 苦諦 Cn: kǔdì; Jp: kutai; Vi: khổ đế; Mn: зовлон, zovlon)
Truth of the origin (samudaya) of dukkha (Sanskrit: samudayāryasatya; Bur: သမုဒယ thamodaya; Thai: สมุทัย; 集諦 Cn: jídì; Jp: jittai; Vi: tập khổ đế; ; Mn: зовлонгийн шалтгаан, zovlongiin shaltgaan)
Truth of the cessation (nirodha) of dukkha (Sanskrit: duḥkhanirodhāryasatya; Bur: နိရောဓ niyawdha; Thai: นิโรธ; 滅諦 Cn: mièdì; Jp: mettai; Vi: diệt khổ đế; Mn: гэтлэх, getlekh)
The path (marga) that leads out of dukkha (Sanskrit: duḥkhanirodhagāminī pratipad; Bur: မဂ် meg; Thai: มรรค; 道諦 Cn: dàodì; Jp: dōtai; Vi: đạo đế; Mn: мөр, mör)
words.name: Four Noble Truths

words.def: fukudo In Zen, term for person who strikes the han
words.name: fukudo

words.def: gassho A position used for greeting, with the palms together and fingers pointing upwards in prayer position; used in various Buddhist traditions, but also used in numerous cultures throughout Asia. It expresses greeting, request, thankfulness, reverence and prayer. Also considered a mudra or inkei of Japanese Shingon. See also: Añjali Mudrā, Namaste, Sampeah and Wai.
words.name: gassho

words.def: geshe A Tibetan Buddhist academic degree in the Gelug tradition, awarded at the conclusion of lengthy studies often lasting nine years or more
words.name: geshe

words.def: gongan, lit. "public case", A meditative method developed in the Chán/Seon/Zen traditions, generally consisting of a problem that defies solution by means of rational thought; see koan
words.name: gongan

words.def: Guan Yin The bodhisattva of compassion in East Asian Buddhism, with full name being Guan Shi Yin. Guan Yin is considered to be the female form of Avalokiteshvara but has been given many more distinctive characteristics.
words.name: Guan Yin

words.def: han In Zen monasteries, wooden board that is struck announcing sunrise, sunset and the end of the day
words.name: han

words.def: Hinayana, lit. "small vehicle", A coinage by the Mahayana for the Buddhist doctrines concerned with the achievement of Nirvana as a Śrāvakabuddha or a Pratyekabuddha, as opposed to a Samyaksambuddha. While sometime thought as derogatory, it means in fact that the Hinayana doctrine is made to save but 1 individual, the one who follows its teachings, just like a 1 place vehicle, while the Mahayana allow the monk to take other people along with him, like a bus or a great plane.
words.name: Hinayana

words.def: Ino, Jp. lit. "bringer of joy to the assembly." Originally from Sanskrit karmadana, lit. bestower of conduct [karma]. In Zen, the supervisor of the meditation hall [sodo]. One of the six senior temple administrators.
words.name: Ino

words.def: jhana Meditative contemplation; more often associated with śamatha practices than vipaśyana. See also: shamata, samadhi, samapatti
words.name: jhana

words.def: jisha In Zen, a senior priest's attendant
words.name: jisha

words.def: jukai Zen public ordination ceremony wherein a lay student receives certain Buddhist precepts.
words.name: jukai

words.def: karma, lit. "action", The law of cause and effect in Buddhism
words.name: karma

words.def: kensho In Zen, enlightenment; has the same meaning as satōri, but is customary used for an initial awakening experience
words.name: kensho

words.def: khyenpo, also khenpo, An academic degree similar to a doctorate in theology, philosophy, and psychology
words.name: khyenpo

words.def: khanti patience
words.name: khanti

words.def: kinhin Zen walking meditation
words.name: kinhin

words.def: koan A story, question, problem or statement generally inaccessible to rational understanding, yet may be accessible to Intuition
words.name: koan

words.def: ksanti The practice of exercising patience toward behaviour or situations that might not necessarily deserve it—it is seen as a conscious choice to actively give patience as a gift, rather than being in a state of oppression in which one feels obligated to act in such a way.
words.name: ksanti

words.def: kyosaku In Zen, a flattened stick used to strike the shoulders during zazen, to help overcome fatigue or reach satori
words.name: kyosaku

words.def: lama A Tibetan teacher or master; equivalent to Sanskrit "guru"
words.name: lama

words.def: lineage The official record of the historical descent of dharma teachings from one teacher to another; by extension, may refer to a tradition
words.name: lineage

words.def: Madhyamaka Buddhist philosophical school, founded by Nagarjuna. Members of this school are called Madhyamikas
words.name: Madhyamaka

words.def: mahabhuta four great elements in traditional Buddhist thought
words.name: mahabhuta

words.def: mahamudra A method of direct introduction the understanding of sunyata, of samsara and that the two are inseparable
words.name: mahamudra

words.def: mahasiddha litt. great spiritual accomplishment. A yogi in Tantric Buddhism, often associated with the highest levels of enlightenment
words.name: mahasiddha

words.def: Mahayana, lit. "great vehicle", A major branch of Buddhism practiced in China, Tibet, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, and Taiwan. Main goal is to achieve buddhahood or samyaksambuddha
words.name: Mahayana

words.def: Maitreya The Buddha of the future epoch
words.name: Maitreya

words.def: makyo In Zen, unpleasant or distracting thoughts or illusions that occur during zazen
words.name: makyo

words.def: Māna conceit, arrogance, misconception
words.name: Māna

words.def: mandala a spiritual and ritual symbol representing the Universe
words.name: mandala

words.def: mantra Chant used primarily to aid concentration, to reach enlightenment. The best-known Buddhist mantra is possibly Om mani padme hum
words.name: mantra

words.def: Mappo The "degenerate" Latter Day of the Law. A time period supposed to begin 2,000 years after Sakyamuni Buddha's passing and last for "10,000 years"; follows the two 1,000-year periods of Former Day of the Law (正法 Cn: zhèngfǎ; Jp: shōbō) and of Middle Day of the Law (像法 Cn: xiàngfǎ; Jp: zōhō). During this degenerate age, chaos will prevail and the people will be unable to attain enlightenment through the word of Sakyamuni Buddha. See the Three periods
words.name: Mappo

words.def: metta loving kindness
words.name: metta

words.def: Middle Way The practice of avoidance of extreme views and lifestyle choices
words.name: Middle Way

words.def: (right) mindfulness The practice whereby a person is intentionally aware of his or her thoughts and actions in the present moment, non-judgmentally. The 7th step of the Noble Eightfold Path
words.name: (right) mindfulness

words.def: moksha Liberation
words.name: moksha

words.def: mokugyo A wooden drum carved from one piece, usually in the form of a fish
words.name: mokugyo

words.def: mondo In Zen, a short dialogue between teacher and student
words.name: mondo

words.def: mudra lit. "seal", A gesture made with hands and fingers in meditation
words.name: mudra

words.def:
namo An exclamation showing reverence; devotion. Often placed in front of the name of an object of veneration, e.g., a Buddha's name or a sutra (Nam(u) Myōhō Renge Kyō), to express devotion to it. Defined in Sino-Japanese as 帰命 kimyō: to base one's life upon, to devote (or submit) one's life to
Derivatives:

Namo Amitabha
words.name: namo

words.def: nekkhamma renunciation
words.name: nekkhamma

words.def: Nirvana/Nibbana Extinction or extinguishing; ultimate enlightenment in the Buddhist tradition
words.name: Nirvana/Nibbana

words.def: Nikaya, lit. "volume", The Buddhist texts in Pāli
words.name: Nikaya

words.def:
Noble Eightfold Path

Right View (Pāli: sammā-diṭṭhi; Sanskrit: samyag-dṛṣṭi; 正見 Cn: zhèngjiàn; Vi: chính kiến)
Right Thought (Pāli: sammā-saṅkappa; Sanskrit: samyak-saṃkalpa; 正思唯 Cn: zhèngsīwéi; Vi: chính tư duy)
These 2 constitute the path of Wisdom (Pāli: paññā; Sanskrit: prajñā)
Right Speech (Pāli: sammā-vācā; Sanskrit: samyag-vāk; 正語 Cn: zhèngyǔ; Vi: chính ngữ)
Right Action (Pāli: sammā-kammanta; Sanskrit: samyak-karmānta; 正業 Cn: zhèngyè; Vi: chính nghiệp)
Right Living (Pāli: sammā-ājīva; Sanskrit: samyag-ājīva; 正命 Cn: zhèngmìng; Vi: chính mệnh)
These 3 constitute the path of Virtue (Pāli: sīla; Sanskrit: śīla)
Right Effort (Pāli: sammā-vāyāma; Sanskrit: samyag-vyāyāma; 正精進 Cn: zhèngjīngjìn; Vi: chính tinh tiến)
Right Mindfulness (Pāli: sammā-sati; Sanskrit: samyag-smṛti; 正念 Cn: zhèngniàn; Vi: chính niệm)
Right Concentration (Pāli: sammā-samādhi; Sanskrit: samyak-samādhi; 正定 Cn: zhèngdìng; Vi: chính định)
The last 3 constitute the path of Concentration (Pāli, Sanskrit: samādhi)
words.name: Noble Eightfold Path

words.def: oryoki A set of bowls used in a Zen eating ceremony
words.name: oryoki

words.def: osho A term used to address a monk of the Zen Buddhist tradition. Originally reserved for high-ranking monks, it has since been appropriated for everyday use when addressing any male member of the Zen clergy
words.name: osho

words.def: pabbajja, (a layperson) leaving home to join a community of monks and nuns (lit. "to go forth")
words.name: pabbajja

words.def:
panca skandha The five constituent elements into which an individual is analyzed. They are:

"form": Pāli, Sanskrit: rūpa; Bu: ရူပ yupa; 色 Cn: sè; Jp: shiki
"sensation": Pāli, Sanskrit: vedanā; Bu: ဝေဒန wedana; 受 Cn: shòu; Jp: ju
"cognition": Pāli: saññā; Sanskrit: saṃjñā; Bu: သညာ thinnya; 想 Cn: xiàng; Jp: sō
"mental formations": Pāli: saṅkhāra; Sanskrit: saṃskāra; Bu: သင်္ခါရ thinkhaya; 行 Cn: xíng; Jp: gyō
"consciousness": Pāli: viññāṇa; Sanskrit: vijñāna; Bu: ဝိညာဉ် winyin; 識 Cn: shí; Jp: shiki
words.name: panca skandha

words.def: Panchen Lama The second highest ranking lama in the Gelugpa sect of Tibetan Buddhism. after the Dalai Lama
words.name: Panchen Lama

words.def: paññā, see prajna
words.name: paññā

words.def: paramartha Absolute, as opposed to merely conventional, truth or reality; see also samvrti
words.name: paramartha

words.def: paramita, lit. "reaching the other shore," usually rendered in English as "perfection." The Mahayana practices for obtaining enlightenment; giving, ethics, patience, effort, concentration and wisdom
words.name: paramita

words.def: parinibbana/parinirvana The final nibbana/nirvana
words.name: parinibbana/parinirvana

words.def: Pointing-out instruction The direct introduction to the nature of mind in the lineages of Essence Mahamudra and Dzogchen. A root guru is the master who gives the 'pointing-out instruction' so that the disciple recognizes the nature of mind
words.name: Pointing-out instruction

words.def: prajna/paññā "wisdom", "insight"
words.name: prajna/paññā

words.def:
pratitya-samutpada "Dependent origination," the view that no phenomenon exists (or comes about) without depending on other phenomena or conditions around it. In English also called "conditioned genesis," "dependent co-arising," "interdependent arising," etc.
A famous application of dependent origination is the Twelve Nidana, or 12 inter-dependences (Sanskrit: dvādaśāṅgapratītyasamutpāda; 十二因緣, 十二因縁 Cn: shíàr yīnyuán; Jp: jūni innen; Vi: thập nhị nhân duyên), which are:

Ignorance (Pāli: avijjā; Sanskrit: avidyā; 無明 Cn: wúmíng; Jp: mumyō; Vi: vô minh; Mn: мунхрахуй, munhrahui)
Ignorance creates Mental Formation (Pāli: saṅkhāra; Sanskrit: saṃskāra; 行 Cn: xíng; Jp: gyō; Vi: hành; Mn: хуран үйлдэхүй, khuran uildehui)
Mental Formation creates Consciousness (Pāli: viññāṇa; Sanskrit: vijñāna; 識 Cn: shí; Jp: shiki; Vi: thức; Mn: тийн мэдэхүй, tiin medehui)
Consciousness creates Name & Form (Pāli, Sanskrit: nāmarūpa; 名色 Cn: míngsè; Jp: myōshiki; Vi: danh sắc; Mn: нэр өнгө, ner öngö)
Name & Form create Sense Gates (Pāli: saḷāyatana; Sanskrit: ṣaḍāyatana; 六入 or 六処 Cn: liùrù; Jp: rokunyū or rokusho; Vi: lục căn; Mn: төрөн түгэхүй, törön tugehui)
Sense Gates create Contact (Pāli: phassa; Sanskrit: sparśa; 觸, 触 Cn: chù; Jp: soku; Vi: xúc; Mn: хүрэлцэхүй, khureltsehui)
Contact creates Feeling (Pāli, Sanskrit: vedanā; 受 Cn: shòu; Jp: ju; Vi: thụ; Mn: сэрэхүй, serehui)
Feeling creates Craving (Pāli: taṇhā; Sanskrit: tṛṣṇā; 愛 Cn: ài; Jp: ai; Vi: ái; Mn: хурьцахуй, khuritsahui)
Craving creates Clinging (Pāli, Sanskrit: upādāna; 取 Cn: qǔ; Jp: shu; Vi: thủ; Mn: авахуй, avahui)
Clinging creates Becoming (Pāli, Sanskrit: bhava; 有 Cn: yǒu; Jp: u; Vi: hữu; Mn: сансар, sansar)
Becoming creates Birth (Pāli, Sanskrit: jāti; 生 Cn: shēng; Jp: shō; Vi: sinh; Mn: төрөхүй, töröhui )
Birth leads to Aging & Death (Pāli, Sanskrit: jarāmaraṇa; 老死 Cn: láosǐ; Jp: rōshi; Vi: lão tử; Mn: өтлөх үхэхүй, ötlöh uhehui)
words.name: pratitya-samutpada

words.def: Pratyekabuddha/Paccekabuddha, lit. "a buddha by his own", A buddha who reaches enlightenment on his own
words.name: Pratyekabuddha/Paccekabuddha

words.def: Pure Land Buddhism A large branch of Mahayana, dominantly in East Asia. The goal of Pure Land Buddhism is to be reborn in the Western sukhavati of Amitabha, either as a real place or within the mind, through the other-power of repeating the Buddha's name, nianfo or nembutsu.
words.name: Pure Land Buddhism

words.def: purisa The practicing Buddhist community as a whole; sangha and laity
words.name: purisa

words.def: rebirth The process of continuity of life after death
words.name: rebirth

words.def: refuge Usually in the form of "take refuge in the Three Jewels"
words.name: refuge

words.def: Rigpa, the knowledge that ensues from recognizing one's nature
words.name: Rigpa

words.def: Rinpoche, lit. "precious one", An honorific title for a respected Tibetan lama, such as a tulku
words.name: Rinpoche

words.def: Rinzai Zen sect emphasizing koan study; named for master Linji Yixuan
words.name: Rinzai

words.def: Rohatsu A day traditionally honored as the day of the Buddha's enlightenment. While deep in meditation under a bodhi tree, he attained enlightenment upon seeing the morning star just at dawn; celebrated on the 8th day either of December or of the 12th month of the lunar calendar
words.name: Rohatsu

words.def: roshi, lit. "Master", An honorific given to Zen teachers in the Rinzai and Obaku sects.
words.name: roshi

words.def: sacca truthfulness
words.name: sacca

words.def: samanera/shramanera A male novice monk, who, after a year or until the ripe age of 20, will be considered for the higher Bhikkhu ordination
words.name: samanera/shramanera

words.def: samatha Mental stabilization; tranquility meditation. Distinguished from vipassanā meditation
words.name: samatha

words.def: samsara The cycle of birth and rebirth; the world as commonly experienced
words.name: samsara

words.def: samu Work, conceived as a part of Zen training.[2]
words.name: samu

words.def: samvrti Conventional, as opposed to absolute, truth or reality; see also paramartha
words.name: samvrti

words.def: sangha The community of Buddhist monks and nuns. Teachers and practitioners.
words.name: sangha

words.def: Sanlun Buddhist philosophical school based on the Madhyamaka school
words.name: Sanlun

words.def: sanzen A formal interview with a teacher in many traditions of Zen. Similar to dokusan
words.name: sanzen

words.def: satori Awakening; understanding. A Japanese term for enlightenment
words.name: satori

words.def: sayadaw Burmese meditation master
words.name: sayadaw

words.def: seichu In the Zen Buddhist calendar, a period of intensive, formal monastic training. It is typically characterized by week-long Daisesshins and periodic sanzen
words.name: seichu

words.def: sesshin A Zen retreat where practitioners meditate, eat and work together for several days
words.name: sesshin

words.def: shikantaza Soto Zen. "Only concentrated on sitting" is the main practice of the Soto school of Japanese Zen Buddhism
words.name: shikantaza

words.def: shunyata Emptiness; see also Nagarjuna
words.name: shunyata

words.def: Sikhī Buddha Buddha of Knowledge
words.name: Sikhī Buddha

words.def: sila "morals", "morality", "ethics": precepts
words.name: sila

words.def: Sōtō Sect of Zen emphasizing shikantaza as the primary mode of practice; see also Dōgen
words.name: Sōtō

words.def: store consciousness The base consciousness (alayavijnana) taught in Yogacara Buddhism
words.name: store consciousness

words.def: sukha happiness; ease; pleasure; bliss
words.name: sukha

words.def: sutra Scripture; originally referred to short aphoristic sayings and collections thereof
words.name: sutra

words.def: Sutra Pitaka The second basket of the Tripiṭaka canon, the collection of all Buddha's teachings
words.name: Sutra Pitaka

words.def: tangaryō A period of waiting for admission into a Zen monastery at the gate, lasting anywhere from one day to several weeks—depending on the quality of one's sitting. Refers to the room traveling monks stay in when visiting, or await admittance into the sōdō.
words.name: tangaryō

words.def: tanha Craving or desire
words.name: tanha

words.def: Tanto In Zen, one of the main temple leaders, lit."head of the tan." In a Zen temple, the Tanto is one of two officers (with the Godo) in charge monks' training.[2]
words.name: Tanto

words.def: tantra Esoteric religious practices, including yoga, mantra, etc. See also Vajrayana.
words.name: tantra

words.def: Tathagata one of the Buddha's ten epithets
words.name: Tathagata

words.def: tathagatagarbha Buddha-nature or the seed of enlightenment
words.name: tathagatagarbha

words.def: teisho A presentation by a Zen master during a sesshin. Rather than an explanation or exposition in the traditional sense, it is intended as a demonstration of Zen realisation
words.name: teisho

words.def: tenzo In Zen, the head cook for a sesshin. In Zen temples, the officer in charge of the kitchen
words.name: tenzo

words.def: Theravada, lit. "words of the elders", Most popular form of Buddhism in Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka.
words.name: Theravada

words.def: thera or their, lit. "elder", Honorific applied to senior monks and nuns in the Theravada tradition.
words.name: theratheir

words.def: Three Jewels Three things that Buddhists take refuge in: the Buddha, his teachings (Dharma) and the community of realized practitioners (Sangha), and in return look toward for guidance (see also Refuge (Buddhism))
words.name: Three Jewels

words.def:
Three periods

Three divisions of the time following the historical Buddha's passing: the Former (or Early) Day of the Law (正法 Cn: zhèngfǎ; Jp: shōbō), the first thousand years; the Middle Day of the Law (像法 Cn: xiàngfǎ; Jp: zōhō), the second thousand years; and the Latter Day of the Law (末法 Cn: mòfǎ; Jp: mappō), which is to last for 10,000 years.
The three periods are significant to Mahayana adherents, particularly those who hold the Lotus Sutra in high regard; e.g., Tiantai (Tendai) and Nichiren Buddhists, who believe that different Buddhist teachings are valid (i.e., able to lead practitioners to enlightenment) in each period due to the different capacity to accept a teaching (機根 Cn: jīgēn; Jp: kikon) of the people born in each respective period.
The three periods are further divided into five five-hundred year periods (五五百歳 Cn: wǔ wǔbǎi suì; Jp: go no gohyaku sai), the fifth and last of which was prophesied to be when the Buddhism of Sakyamuni would lose all power of salvation and a new Buddha would appear to save the people. This time period would be characterized by unrest, strife, famine, and other, natural disasters.
The three periods and the five five-hundred year periods are described in the Sutra of the Great Assembly (大集経 Cn: dàjí jīng; Jp: Daishutu-kyō, Daijuku-kyō, Daijikkyō, or Daishukkyō). Descriptions of the three periods also appear in other sutras, some of which ascribe different lengths of time to them (although all agree that Mappō will last for 10,000 years).
words.name: Three periods

words.def:
Three Poisons or Three Fires

The three primary causes of unskillful action that lead to the creation of "negative" karma; the three root kleshas:


Attachment (Pāli: lobha; Sanskrit: rāga; Tib.: འདོད་ཆགས་ 'dod chags)
Aversion (Pali: doha; Sanskrit: dveṣa; Tib.: ཞེ་སྡང་ zhe sdang; Mn: урин хилэн, urin khilen; 瞋 Cn: chēn; Jp: jin; Vi: sân)
Ignorance (Pāli: moha; Sanskrit: moha; Tib.: གཏི་མུག་ gti mug)
words.name: Three PoisonsThree Fires

words.def: Tiantai/Tendai A Mahayana school of China that teaches the supremacy of the Lotus Sutra
words.name: Tiantai/Tendai

words.def:
trailõkya The 3 "regions" of the world:

Kamaloka or Kamadhatu: world of desires (Sanskrit, Pāli: kāmaloka, kāmadhātu; Tibetan: འདོད་ཁམས་ `dod khams; Mn: амармагийн орон, amarmagiin oron; 欲界 Cn: yùjiè, Jp: yokkai Vi: dục giới)
Rupaloka or Rupadhatu: world of form (Sanskrit: rūpaloka, rūpadhātu; Tibetan: གཟུགས་ཁམས་ gzugs khams; Mn: дүрстийн орон, durstiin oron; 色界 Cn: sèjiè; Jp: shikikai , Vi: sắc giới)
Arupaloka or Arupadhatu: world without form or desire (Sanskrit: arūpaloka, arūpadhātu; Tibetan: གཟུགས་མེད་ཁམས་ gzugs med khams; Mn: дүрсгүйн орон, dursquin oron; 無色界 Cn: wú sèjiè, Jp: mushikikai Vi: vô sắc giới)
words.name: trailõkya

words.def:
trikaya The 3 "bodies" of Buddha:

Dharma-kaya (Sanskrit: dharmakāya; 法身 Cn: fǎshēn; Jp: hosshin; Vi: pháp thân)
Sambhoga-kaya (Sanskrit: saṃbhogakāya; 報身 Cn: bàoshēn; Jp: hōshin; Vi: báo thân)
Nirmana-kaya (Sanskrit: nirmāṇakāya; 應身,化身,応身 Cn: yìngshēn; Jp: ōjin; Vi: ứng thân)
words.name: trikaya

words.def:
Tripitaka The "Three Baskets"; canon containing the sacred texts for Buddhism (Pāli)

Vinaya Pitaka (Pāli, Sanskrit: Vinaya-piṭaka; Tib: འདུལ་བའི་སྡེ་སྣོད་ `dul ba`i sde snod; Mn: винайн аймаг сав vinain aimag sav; 律藏, 律蔵 Cn: lǜzàng; Jp: Ritsuzō; Vi: Luật tạng)
Sutra Pitaka (Pāli: Sutta-piṭaka; Sanskrit: Sūtra-piṭaka; Tib: མདོ་སྡེའི་སྡེ་སྣོད་ mdo sde`i sde snod; Mn: судрын аймаг сав sudriin aimag sav; 經藏, 経蔵 Cn: jīngzàng; Jp: Kyōzō; Vi: Kinh tạng)
Abhidhamma Pitaka (Pāli: Abhidhamma-piṭaka; Sanskrit: Abhidharma-piṭaka; Tib: མངོན་པའི་སྡེ་སྣོད་ mngon pa`i sde snod; Mn: авидармын аймаг сав avidarmiin aimag sav; 論藏, 論蔵 Cn: lùnzàng; Jp: Ronzō; Vi: Luận tạng)
words.name: Tripitaka

words.def: Triratna/Tiratana, see Three Jewels above
words.name: Triratna/Tiratana

words.def: trsna, see tanha above
words.name: trsna

words.def: tulku A re-incarnated Tibetan teacher
words.name: tulku

words.def: upadana Clinging; the 9th link of Pratitya-Samutpada; the Ninth Twelve Nidanas
words.name: upadana

words.def: Upajjhaya spiritual teacher
words.name: Upajjhaya

words.def: upasaka A lay follower of Buddhism
words.name: upasaka

words.def: upasika A female lay follower
words.name: upasika

words.def:
upaya Expedient though not necessarily ultimately true. Originally used as a polemical device against other schools - calling them "merely" expedient, lacking in ultimate truth, later used against one's own school to prevent students form forming attachments to doctrines
In Mahayana, exemplified by the Lotus Sutra, upaya are the useful means that Buddhas (and Buddhist teachers) use to free beings into enlightenment
words.name: upaya

words.def: upekkha equanimity
words.name: upekkha

words.def: urna A concave circular dot on the forehead between the eyebrows
words.name: urna

words.def: Vajrayana, The third major branch, alongside Hinayana and Mahayana, according to Tibetan Buddhism's view of itself
words.name: Vajrayana

words.def: Vairocana,
words.name: Vairocana

words.def: Vāsanā habitual tendencies or dispositions
words.name: Vāsanā

words.def: Vinaya Pitaka, The first basket of the Tripitaka canon, which deals with the rules of monastic life
words.name: Vinaya Pitaka

words.def: vipassana Usually translated as "Insight" meditation, most associated with the Theravāda tradition, but also present in some other traditions such as Tiantai. Often combined with śamatha meditation
words.name: vipassana

words.def: viriya energy, enthusiastic perseverance
words.name: viriya

words.def: yāna divisions or schools of Buddhism according to their type of practice (lit. "vehicle")
words.name: yāna

words.def: zazen Sitting meditation as practiced in the Zen School of Buddhism
words.name: zazen

words.def: Zen School A branch of Mahayana originating in China that originally emphasizes non-dualism and intuition. Modern monastic forms have a strong emphasis on zazen (Korean) or on zazen combined with militaristic top-down hazing (Japanese)
words.name: Zen School

words.def: zendo In Zen, a hall where zazen is practiced
words.name: zendo
